ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ADMISSION TO SCHOOLS
(Priority)


    1. Dr Tan Cheng Bock asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education why priority is given to the 3rd

Column: 162

child, who has an elder brother or sister studying in the school, over the 1st or 2nd child with a parent who has been sterilized after the birth of the 1st or 2nd child and whether this move is unfair to parents who have been given to believe that sterilization after the 2nd child would give their children priority of admission to schools over 3rd child siblings whose parents are not even required to be sterilized.

     The Minister of State of Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, Phase 1 registration is for a second or third child who has an elder brother or sister studying in the same school. The reasons for this are obvious. Parents need not transport their children to different schools and the elder brother or sister can look after the younger one.

    Phase 2 registration is more extensive. It includes, among others, children of parents who have direct connections with the school;

Column: 163

parents, brothers or sisters who are former students of the school: members of the advisory or management committees or staff of the school. Parents who have undergone sterilization after the first or second child are accorded the highest priority under Phase 2, namely, Phase 2A. Far from being unfairly treated, parents in this category have priority under Phase 2A which is valid at any school. In contrast, Phase 1 priority applies only at a school which the siblings are attending.

    I do not know how the hon. Member has been led to believe that sterilized parents have been promised priority by the Ministry over third child siblings whose parents are not sterilized. The Ministry has never made such a promise.

    The matter raised by the hon. Member is academic. Since 1977, the number of children of parents sterilized after the birth of the first or second child varied between 1,100 and 1,779. Last year, it was 1,379. In every instance, the children of sterilized parents in this category have been placed in the schools of their first choice.

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock (Ayer Rajah): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, before I ask my supplementary question, I would just like to enlighten the House on the family planning programme of our nation.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: Dr Tan, will you please keep it brief because we have quite a few questions today?

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock: Yes. Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I would like to draw the attention of this House to the Family Planning and Population Board which was established by an Act of Parliament and inaugurated in January 1966. I refer you to the Family Planning Board Paper 45 and the Family Planning Board Paper 52.1. I would also like to draw the attention of the House to a set of social policies introduced in 1969-70.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: Dr Tan, what is your supplementary question?

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock: Sir, I think I need to explain before I come to the supplementary

Column: 164

question. I think you must allow me to continue, Sir.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: Yes.

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock: Thank you very much. These policies were further intensified in 1972. These include, among others, higher priority for choice primary schools for children, one of whose parents has been sterilized after one or two children. I ask, higher priority over whom? Obviously it must be over those who are not sterilized.

    In line with our national policy in 1975, a total of 9,495 women were sterilized. 16% of those who ligated did so after one or two children, Why did I choose 1975? I chose 1975 because children born then will be going to school now. 16% works out to 1,520. These 1,520 mothers made a bold decision. They underwent an operative procedure and not without its hazards of surgery and anaesthesia, only to realize six years later that what they were promised in 1975 did not materialize to their expectation in 1981. They may have other reasons for sterilization but one of their considerations is priority over those not sterilized after two or three children. This is the policy of our family planning. Unless the Ministry of Education thinks otherwise, I feel very sorry for the Family Planning Board and I am wondering how are they going to explain to the people in future.

     The First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Point of order, Sir. Is the hon. Member delivering a speech or asking a supplementary question?

     Mr Deputy Speaker: I have asked the Member for his supplementary question. Dr Tan, please let us have your supplementary question. If you cannot make up your mind, I will have to rule you out of order,

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock: Sir, if you stop me at this stage, it is not very fair. I think I must continue further.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: Then get on with your point, please.

Column: 165



     Dr Tan Cheng Bock: What I want to point out is that we must not give Singaporeans the impression that we -

     Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I must insist that the hon. Member complies with Standing Orders. This is Question Time. I want to know what his supplementary question is.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: Dr Tan, let us have your supplementary question. If not, I have to call on Mr Ho for Question 2.

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock: My question is whether the Ministry of Education has taken into account the family planning policy of our nation. The Minister of State has said that the Ministry of Education has not made any promise to the people of Singapore on this priority. Can the Minister of State of Education clarify this point for this House?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I have already said that those parents who were sterilized after one or two children have the highest priority under Phase 2 at any school in Singapore.

    This was the same understanding which the Ministry announced in 1974. I refer the hon. Member to the Straits Times of 22nd July 1974 in which we said that if one of the parents had undergone sterilization, the children would be given priority under Phase 2. This is applicable to all schools.

SALARY OF TEACHERS


    2. Mr Ho See Beng asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education why a primary school teacher who applied for a teaching post in a secondary school has been told that he would not be paid salary of a secondary school teacher despite approval of his application.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, there does not exist a salary scale for secondary school teachers. Teachers' salaries are determined by academic qualifications and experience. Teachers are broadly classified into two groups, university graduates and non-

Column: 166

graduates, and they are placed on separate salary scales. Generally, graduate teachers teach in upper secondary schools and junior colleges and non-graduate teachers teach in primary schools and lower secondary classes.

    A transfer from a primary school to a secondary school does not entitle the teacher to a graduate's pay.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Sir, can the Minister of State tell this House how does a Taiwan university graduate, who is a primary school teacher, go about applying for a teaching post in a secondary school and get a secondary school teacher's pay?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, I have said that there is no secondary school teacher's pay as opposed to primary school teacher's pay. It is a question of whether the teacher is a graduate and accepted as such by the Public Service Commission. If the teacher has a degree and applies to the Public Service Commission and is accepted as such as a graduate teacher, then he will be put on the graduate teacher's salary scale, irrespective of whether he is in a primary school or a secondary school.

     Mr Ho See Bong: Sir, how does one get to know whether a Taiwan university degree is recognized by the Government or not?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the recognition of university degrees for the civil service is determined by the Public Service Commission.

     Mr Ho See Bong: Sir, it seems to me that the Ministry of Education does not recognize -

     Mr Deputy Speaker: Mr Ho, are you raising a supplementary question?

     Mr Ho See Beng: Yes, I am. Does the Ministry of Education only accept his service but does not recognize his degree?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, people who want to become teachers apply to the Public Service Commission to be employed as teachers. The Public Service Commission at the interview decides whether or not to recognize his or her qualifications. Dr Toh Chin Chye;

PUPILS LEAVING SCHOOL BEFORE PSLE
(Particulars)


    3. Dr Koh Lip Lin asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (a) what was the average percentage of pupils who left school before sitting for the PSLE during the past two years; (b) at what stage did most of them leave school; and (c) what were the main reasons for their doing so.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, during the last two years the total number of primary school students who left the school system before the PSLE was 1.6% of the total enrolment in 1 979 and 0.3% in 1980. These figures do not include those pupils who fail badly in the schools and are transferred to the basic course previously and now to the monolingual course to continue their education. These pupils will continue in the school system until they are ready for enrolment at the VITB. The majority of premature school leavers were at the Primary 6 level. For example, in 1979, out of 4,732 premature school leavers, 3,488 or 74% left at Primary 6. The trend was similar in 1980.

    There are various reasons why pupils leave school prematurely. Some leave because they are required to supplement the family income through employment. Others do so because of family problems. The majority do so because they have lost interest in schooling after repeated failure in their studies and because of inadequate parental guidance and support.

     Dr Koh Lip Lin (Nee Soon): Sir, I would like to ask the Hon. Minister of State whether the Ministry has carried out or will be carrying out any study to find out what happened to these students who leave school before the PSLE, especially those who have lost interest in their studies.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, the answer to the Member's question is "Yes". The Ministry has been carrying out studies of pupils who have left the school system.

Column: 168



     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi (Kampong Kembangan): Sir, noting the statement by the Minister of State that some of the students who dropped out after PSLE had to do something to supplement the income of the family, does this mean that they are taking on some jobs? If so, what type of jobs, and whether this will contravene any labour laws of this country?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, on the question of contravening the labour laws in this country, the Member should address the question to the Minister for Labour.

     Dr Toh Chin Chye (Rochore): Sir, just to follow up, may I ask the Minister of State of Education this question: Can he attribute the number of drop-outs in primary schools to the restructuring of the education policy?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, before the restructuring of the school system, those who failed badly were put on the basic course for a number of years until such time when they became ready for entry into the VITB. Since the restructuring of the education system, many of these students would go into the monolingual stream, again for a number of years of basic education, before joining the VITB. I think it is too early to say whether the revised education system is resulting in more students not making it through the school system.

CHINESE NAMES IN PINYIN
(Use in PSLE and GCE certificates)


    4. Dr Koh Lip Lin asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education whether the names of Chinese students in Pinyin will be used in PSLE and GCE certificates.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Sir, the names of all ethnic Chinese pupils in the Pre-primary and Primary 1 classes have been mandarinized and transcribed in Hanyu Pinyin. By 1982 all Chinese pupils will have their names mandarinized. When these pupils sit for the PSLE, GCE 'O' and 'A' levels in 1982, they will use their names in Hanyu Pinyin with their statutory

Column: 169

names in brackets. Their Hanyu Pinyin names will, therefore, appear on the certificates with the statutory names in brackets.

     Dr Koh Lip Lin: Sir, I would like to ask the Hon. Minister of State whether principals and teachers will also be asked to use their mandarinized names in Pinyin. If so, when will they be asked to do so? If not, will our students not be wondering why they should use Pinyin names and not their teachers and principals?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, the Ministry of Education has no plans at the moment to ask teachers to mandarinize their names. The programme applies only to school children.

ANG MO KIO NEW TOWN
(New primary schools)


    5. Mr Lim Boon Heng asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (a) how many new primary schools will be completed in Ang Mo Kio New Town in time for the commencement of the new school year in January 1982; and (b) whether these new schools, together with the existing schools, will be able to provide enough places for all Primary One students living in Ang Mo Kio New Town.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Sir, eight new primary schools are being built in the Ang Mo Kio New Town area. Four of them, Ang Mo Kio North, Chong Li, Da Giao and Hong Dao, will be completed in time to take in Primary 1 pupils from January 1982. The other four, Ang Mo Kio South, Chong De, Chong Shan and Jing Shan, will be completed sometime in 1982. Although these four schools will not be ready before January 1982, pupils can register and are, in fact, being registered for these schools. They will be having their classes in the existing schools and the four new schools will be completed before 1982. As soon-as the other schools are ready in 1982, they will be transferred to their respective schools. The new schools, together with the five existing schools, will have sufficient places for all Primary 1 pupils living in the Ang Mo Kio New Town.

Column: 170



     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi: Could the Hon. Minister of State inform the House who makes the final decision in the naming of primary schools or secondary schools, and what are the general principles adopted in the naming of schools?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, up to now, the final decision for naming of schools is made by the Senior Minister of State of Education. The naming of schools generally follows the names of private schools, which were in those areas that have been passed on to the Government. So the names continue because the assets of these schools will pass over to the Ministry of Education.

    Another principle that is observed is that we try to make use of the name of the location, the road or street in the area concerned.

PERSONNEL MANAGEMENT IN PUBLIC SERVICE
(Improvement of quality)


    6. Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi asked the Minister for Finance what specific steps have been taken to improve the quality of personnel management so as to bring about better teamwork, higher productivity and more harmonious relations in Government Departments, Ministries and Statutory Boards.

     The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, in March this year I said, in answer to a question from the Member for Mountbatten, that the general morale of workers in the Civil Service was excellent. There is no reason to believe that morale has deteriorated or needs special attention.

    While my Ministry, in conjunction with the PSC, has the overall responsibility for the Civil Service, all Ministries are responsible for the day-to-day management and well-being of their staff. They must motivate their staff to maximize productivity. To help them do this job better, my Ministry is studying a suggestion for creating a separate Personnel Officers Service. The intention is to build up a core of career personnel administrators who

Column: 171

can give full-time attention to personnel matters. They would then be posted to Ministries and larger departments to work very much like Personnel Managers and Personnel Officers in companies. The Budget Division of my Ministry would provide the coordination and leadership to these career personnel administrators who in turn would provide useful feedback to the Division.

    My Ministry is also considering a proposal, in accordance with recommendations by the Committee on Productivity, that a Productivity Working Committee be formed to initiate and oversee the implementation of management practices that will promote productivity. Such a Committee would be chaired by the Permanent Secretary of the Budget Division. It would include representatives from other Ministries, besides representatives from the Public Service Commission, Management Services Department, and the Civil Service Institute.

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi: Sir, in thanking the Hon. Minister for informing the House that the morale of the workers in the Civil Service is very high and also about the Personnel Officers Service, could the Minister state what will be the role of the trade unions in the Government departments and statutory boards, in this effort to further improve the industrial relations and personnel system in the Civil Service and in the statutory boards?.

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, these Personnel Officers will conduct themselves like personnel officers in companies in the private sector. That means they will have relations with the trade unions on a day-to-day basis, if necessary, and will consult them in all matters, be it matters relating to day-to-day work or improvements in productivity.

CIVIL SERVICE
(Option of Central Provident Fund
Scheme)


    7. Mr Liew Kok Pun asked the Minister for Finance (a) what percentage of Division 3 and 4 officers in the Civil Service have not opted for the Central Provident Fund scheme

Column: 172

and their reasons for not opting: and (b) whether there is any plan to extend the CPF option to other categories of officers in the Civil Service; if not, whether there are any special reasons for not extending it, and if so, what is the timeframe for implementation.

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, 38% of all Divisions III and IV officers in the Civil Service have not opted for the Central Provident Fund Scheme. They have not been asked to give reasons for their decision but it is probable that they decided not to opt for the CPF Scheme for some or all of the following reasons. First, they did not want to suffer a drop in take-home pay. Second, they did not want to lose medical benefits given by Government upon retirement. Third, they were near to retirement and there was therefore no advantage or less advantage in opting for the CPF Scheme.

    There is no firm plan as yet to extend to Divisions I and 11 officers the option to cross over to the CPF Scheme. Members may remember that the Prime Minister touched on this matter briefly on 17th March 1981 when he replied to questions from the Member for Punggol and the Member for Mountbatten following the Statement he made on the Revision of Salaries of Ministers, Chief Justice and other protocol office holders. The Prime Minister said then that for certain key jobs, like those held by Administrative Officers, we cannot afford to hire and fire. For such persons, a pensionable service is the only kind of service. He also indicated that to hold the loyalty of these officers, there would have to be regular adjustments of their salary and a decent pension. The Government is considering some suggestions to improve the Pensions Scheme. Until this matter is decided, it is best not to give any Service in Divisions I and II the option to cross over from the Pensions Scheme to the CPF Scheme so that the key Services will not feel disadvantaged.

CHARTERED INDUSTRIES OF SINGAPORE PTE. LTD.
(Noise nuisance)


    8. Mr Goh Chee Wee asked the Minister for the Environment whether he is

Column: 173

convinced that the noise generated during the ammunition quality control testings conducted by the Chartered Industries of Singapore Pte. Ltd. is excessive for the locality: and what actions are being taken to reduce the noise level and to minimize the nuisance caused to the residents.

     The Minister for the Environment (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the testing of ammunition at the Chartered Industries at Boon Lay Road has been going on since 1967. These testings are carried out daily from 9.00 am to 2.30 pm and from 3.30 pm to 8.30 pm under controlled conditions. They create noise at levels of about 70-74 decibel (dB) at the residential flats nearby. The noise levels are slightly higher than the background noise level of 64- ,70 dB in the locality. The noise level caused by the testings is no higher than the noise caused by the heavy vehicle moving along Jalan Boon Lay.

    Nevertheless, Chartered Industries has been advised to minimize the noise. They are taking action to appoint an acoustic consultant to carry out a noise control study at the firing range with the intention of reducing the noise level. They will also be required to adjust the time of testing to minimize the nuisance caused to the residents.

WATER-BORNE FEE
(Particulars)


    9. Mr Rohan bin Kamis asked the Minister for the Environment what is the purpose of the "water-borne fee" collected by the Public Utilities Board; what amount has been collected since its introduction up to any convenient date; how this amount collected has been expended and whether the need to maintain the rate for this fee will be reviewed.

     Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Deputy Speaker, Singapore is a compact, urbanized and industrialized state. Over the last 20 years, the Government has built a modern sewerage system to ensure a high standard of public health. Waste water from our homes and industries is collected and treated before dis-

Column: 174

charge into our watercourses or the sea. This has prevented water-borne diseases and the breeding of vectors, such as flies and mosquitoes. The modern sewerage system has also helped to reduce the pollution in our rivers and canals.

    To-date, we have built four sewage treatment works, 118 sewage pumping stations and 1,400 kilometres of sewers. Another two sewage treatment works, costing $127 million at Jurong and Seletar, are under construction.

    Eighty per cent of our population are now served by the modern sewerage system. Because of the effective sewerage system, Singapore is enjoying one of the highest public health standards in the world. We still have isolated outbreaks of contagious diseases, such as typhoid and cholera. Investigations, however, revealed that the harmful germs are food-borne and not waterborne.

    The sewerage infrastructure requires large amounts of capital. From FY 1970 to FY 1980, we have spent $795 million on capital expenditure. We have borrowed US$33.1 million (equivalent to S$78 million) from the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank to partly finance the capital expenditure.

    Since 1970, the Government levies a monthly water-borne fee on all premises with PUB water supply. In addition, a sanitary appliances fee (for toilets and urinals) is collected for premises connected to public sewers. The PUB collects the fees on behalf of the Government. The revenue pays for the depreciation of the capital works, the operating expenditure and interest payment on loans. This is a requirement of the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank. The net surplus of revenue is used to defray part of the capital expenditure.

    From FY 1970 to FY 1980, the amount of water-borne fee collected is $175 million, and the sanitary appliances and other fees are $214.1 million. For the same period, my Ministry spent a total of $260 million on providing sewerage services.

Column: 175



    The present rates of the water-borne fees are 7 cents per cubic metre for domestic premises and 15 cents per cubic metre for non-domestic premises. The sanitary appliances fee is $3 per toilet or urinal.

    The net surplus has fallen in FY 1980. Our operating expenditure has increased because of higher energy and material costs, and wages. Based on existing revenue rates, we will run into a deficit in FY 1982. My Ministry has reviewed the rate of the waterborne fee and an announcement on the revision of the fee will be made shortly.

APPLICATIONS FOR CITIZENSHIP
(Particulars)


    10. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) how many applications for citizenship are still outstanding as at the latest convenient date: and (b) how many persons have applied for citizenship since 1st January, 1981, and how many of them have been granted citizenship.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, as at 31st July, 1981, there were 6,923 outstanding applications for citizenship.     The problems of censorship in Singapore today are more complex than a decade ago, Mass travel has made it very difficult for a society to filter foreign influences. Just as bad money drives out good money, debased values and bizarre life-styles spread from country to country, undermining and eroding established virtues and values. All these have changed the problems of censorship. Technological advances, for example, have brought about the invention of video tapes and video discs which make it possible for films hitherto viewed only in cinema halls to be available for private viewing. This has also introduced new censorship problems as obviously it is easier to monitor what is shown in cinemas than what is viewed at home.

    Video tapes are coming into Singapore in large numbers; some of them are objectionable because of violent or nude scenes while others are outright pornographic. Because of their very compactness, they are easily smuggled in, duplicated and distributed in large numbers. Video libraries have mushroomed, exhibiting and distributing tapes, many of which are either uncensored, objectionable or pornographic. We are a highly urbanized society and in a relatively short time few segments of our population will be left untouched by this media.

    The problem of monitoring and controlling what is communicated through video tapes is a world-wide one. We have no model to emulate in dealing with this problem. The Western countries gave up censorship even before the mass advent of video tapes. So they have not even tried to face up to this problem. In other countries like Japan, censorship is voluntary through the Video Tape Ethics Council. The Japanese are far more permissive in their standards than anything we would contemplate. But somehow there is not the same massive erosion of traditional sexual moralities and the family institution in Japan. What gives their society this strength merits more study by us, which we will do. Hence, I would not want to suggest that with the passage of this Bill we would have found a final solution to the problems of the deleterious and destructive values and life-styles that are prone to be

I have stated before in this House that the video tape distribution and lending business has attracted more than its fair share of crooks and charlatans. For successful supervision of this trade, the close cooperation of the trade is essential. We must evolve a system, over time, which combines Government administrative measures and a large measure of voluntary actions on the part of the trade. To achieve this, we must weed out criminal and irresponsible elements from the trade. Thus the requirement for licensing. Anyone who carries on the business of importing, making, distributing or exhibiting video tapes without a licence or anyone who allows his place to be used by an unlicensed operator will be guilty of an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine not less than $5,000 but not exceeding $20,000 or to an imprisonment term not exceeding six months or to both fine and imprisonment. Under clause 21, the penalty for possession, exhibition and distribution of uncensored tapes is a fine of not less than $100 per copy but not exceeding the aggregate of $20,000.
